title: 109_s1014
content: The Act may be cited as the "Supporting Our Patriotic Businesses Act of 2005". Congress finds that from September 2001 to November 2004, around 410,000 reserve component members were mobilized for military operations. Data shows that 35% of Guard members and Reservists are self-employed or work for small businesses. Activations have caused significant disruptions to small businesses, with owners and key personnel being absent for extended periods. The Office of Veterans Business Development has made efforts to assist small businesses affected by deployments, but resources are stretched thin. Executive Order 13360 has directed the office to provide procurement training programs for service-disabled veterans. This Act aims to mitigate the impact of National Guard and Reservist deployments on small businesses and support veterans with their business needs. Increased funding of $2,000,000 for fiscal year 2006, $2,100,000 for fiscal year 2007, and $2,200,000 for fiscal year 2008 is authorized for the Office of Veterans Business Development. The SBA Advisory Committee on Veterans Business Affairs is permanently extended by amending relevant sections of the Small Business Act and the Veterans Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development Act of 1999. SEC. 5. PROFESSIONAL AND OCCUPATIONAL LICENSING. Amends the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act to include a new section on continuing education requirements for professional and occupational licenses. This section of the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act applies to servicemembers ordered to active duty, exempting them from completing continuing education requirements for their profession during active duty and for 120 days after release. The Servicemembers Civil Relief Act exempts servicemembers on active duty from continuing education requirements for their profession and for 120 days after release. The term 'active duty' is defined in section 101(d) of title 10, United States Code. SEC. 6. Relief from time limitations for veteran-owned small businesses. Section 3(q) of the Small Business Act is amended to provide relief from time limitations for small businesses owned by veterans called to active duty after September 11, 2001. The Small Business Act is amended to provide relief from time limitations for service-disabled veterans who incurred injuries during active duty after September 11, 2001. Upon submission of proper documentation, the time limitation extension shall be granted. The time limitation extension for service-disabled veterans injured during active duty after September 11, 2001, shall be equal to the period of time the veteran was on active duty. SEC. 7 requires counseling for reserve component members on notifying employers of mobilization orders. The counseling must be provided at least once a year. SEC. 8 calls for a study on improving timely notice to employers of National Guard and Reserve members regarding mobilization. The Secretary of Defense is required to conduct a study on improving the notification time for employers of reserve component members called to active duty. The purpose is to identify ways to reduce the time between the call to duty and employer notification. A report on the study is due within 180 days. The Secretary of Defense must conduct a study on improving employer notification time for reserve component members called to active duty. A report with study details and recommendations for legislative or administrative action is due to the Committees on Armed Services and Small Business of Congress within 180 days.
